tags: how to review fic that you like
summary: I’m not big on tooting my own horn, so let me disclaim this first by saying that is not my intent behind posting this screen cap...
caption:
I’m not big on tooting my own horn, so let me disclaim this first by saying that is not my intent behind posting this screen cap of a review that I woke up to this morning. Rather, I’d like to express my heartfelt thanks and explain why, when people leave words like this behind on a work of fiction that you’ve spent hours thinking about, writing and editing, they save the fucking day.

The self-doubt cycle of a writer is endless. It doesn’t matter if you’re writing original fiction or fanfiction, there’s always a stopgap between what you’re making and how you feel about it, and the abysmal middle where you often tell yourself, “I could be doing something better with my time because no one appreciates what I’m doing here.” That voice often likes to pipe up, and it’s often discouraging enough that a lot of people will stop plugging away.

When you stop plugging away, dear writer, you do not progress and you do not pass go and you do not collect one hundred dollars. You do not get better at your craft, and maybe the few people who were enjoying the thing you were writing walk away with a little hole in their hearts where you might’ve given them something to stopper the feels from flowing away when there was no new canon material to fill the void.

Prior to getting this note in my inbox, I’ve been mulling over the, “I should just put this fic on a shelf for a bit,” for about a week. 

How long the thing ought to live on a shelf while I work on something else is never determined. Sometimes they don’t come down off the shelf. 

Reviews like the above, however, are a balm for the lonely craft of writing. Reviews like the above ensure that additional chapters get contemplated and probably written. Reviews like the above make the motherfucking world go round: they paint my days rosey and give them grace.

So to Judgy Fish Caretaker, I say thank you again for quieting my negative self-talk and leaving such a wonderful note behind to wake up to. To everyone else – this person just bought you another chapter.

summary:
Are Monty and Harper going to be that weird Aunt and Uncle who live out in the middle of nowhere? 
When they were talking about...
body:
Are Monty and Harper going to be that weird Aunt and Uncle who live out in the middle of nowhere?


When they were talking about staying there all I could think about was Luke Skywalkers home in Star Wars (His home in a New Hope, not The Last Jedi)

summary: DAMN IT APHRA!!  Get in the damn tie fighter and get out of there!! Well, we know she won’t, she’s still stuck on this rock...
caption:
DAMN IT APHRA!!

Get in the damn tie fighter and get out of there!!

Well, we know she won’t, she’s still stuck on this rock three issues from now when Vader DOES show up.. Oh I am not looking forward to that.

Also I really hope this doesn’t lead to Magna falling out of love with Aphra, cause seeing her say she’s in love with her just makes me squee so loudly.

summary:
☆ Rey Appreciation Week ☆ 

 Day 4: Alternate Universe - Finnrey Tangled AU

 A soldier on the run, Finn is desperate to escape...
caption:
☆ Rey Appreciation Week ☆

Day 4: Alternate Universe - Finnrey Tangled AU

A soldier on the run, Finn is desperate to escape the First Order after he defects from their ranks. He hides in tall tower in the middle of nowhere - only to find a girl! Rey has lived in the tower for as long as she can remember, with occasional visit from her keeper Unkar Plutt. Not only is she the girl with the prettiest face and longest hair he’s ever seen, she can read minds and make things float! Is she the long lost protege of the last known Jedi, Luke Skywalker? Is she the answer to the decades-long war between the First Order and the Republic? Time will tell, but Finn must first convince her to leave with him…

summary: Why Carrie Fisher thought 'Star Wars' would be the end of her career
title: Why Carrie Fisher thought 'Star Wars' would be the end of her career
body:
Before becoming an intergalactic icon, Carrie Fisher was a promising up-and-comer famous for being the daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher. And even though she landed a lead role in a major studio film, Carrie wondered whether appearing in the strange new sci-fi adventure titled Star Wars would do irreparable damage to her acting career.

Her younger brother, Todd Fisher, was by her side during the making of George Lucas‘s film and at the world premiere. He joined Yahoo Entertainment in Los Angeles to share what it was like to accompany Carrie on the cusp of superstardom.

“She was squeezing my hand, panicked.”

“I was with [Carrie] in England when the movie was being made,” says Fisher, whose new memoir, My Girls, offers a peek at what it was like to grow up in Hollywood with Carrie and mother Debbie Reynolds. “It was cool. There was these big sets and it had a certain amount of impressiveness to the sets. But you know you couldn’t obviously see any of the effects so you don’t know what’s coming. And you know, people [thought Lucas was] all nuts. He’s got this giant 7-foot carpet running around called a Wookiee. …

“So we’re sitting in the parking lot waiting to go into the screening,” Fisher continued. “Now, this is the first time anybody’s seen anything. This is days before it comes out to the theaters. She’s smoking, chain-smoking, drinking —  Coca-Cola in one hand, cigarette in the other hand. She just doesn’t want to go and I’m like, ‘You know we’ve got to go in.’  I’m sitting there watching the lights go down, you know, literally doors are closing. ‘We’ve got to go now.’ So I finally get her to put her cigarette out. By this point there’s nowhere to sit except the front row. So we sit in the front row and it starts and we watch those titles go by and then the battlecruiser flies over and I looked over, and I had her hand, she was squeezing my hand, panicked. I said, ‘This is no B-movie.‘”

Toward the end of her life, Carrie embraced her affected British accent in her scene with the “foul” Grand Moff Tarkin (Peter Cushing), but in 1977 she was horrified that it was being used in the final cut of the film.

“She was she freaked out when that was used because out of nowhere, the whole movie she has no British accent, and all of the sudden she has a British accent,” Fisher told us. “But you know what? I think she was the only one that noticed. I don’t think anybody cared! She was trained at the London Dramatic Academy. And of course they made you do Elizabethan English and such so you did have a tendency, if you’re being dramatic, to break loose with the British accent.”

“As the brother of Princess Leia, I would love it if they would carry on with Carrie.”

When Carrie Fisher died unexpectedly in 2016, the producers of Star Wars had to rework the script to the upcoming Episode IX, due out in 2019 because the actress was to have a major role. Because Leia’s story will not conclude as originally envisioned, and because fans wanted the iconic hero to get a deserving send-off, some launched a petition to have the role recast with Meryl Streep. Others suggested they employ similar technology used in Rogue One and have character return via CGI. Todd himself told the New York Daily News in 2017 that his late sister would appear in the upcoming Episode IX via unused footage. However, Lucasfilm President Kathleen Kennedy refuted that notion in a conversation with Yahoo at Star Wars Celebration a few weeks later, saying, “I have no idea why he said that.” Lucasfilm soon after released a statement saying the studio had “no plans to digitally recreate Carrie Fisher’s performance as Princess or General Leia Organa” in future movies.

Todd knows that the decision is out of his hands, but still hopes The Last Jedi won’t be the last movie Carrie appears in.

“Obviously Lucasfilm and Disney, they own Carrie’s likeness,” he acknowledged. “George owned it [before selling Lucasfilm]. In fact, Carrie famously used to joke that every time she looks in the mirror, she has to send George a couple of bucks. Now Disney’s got it. And what they do with it is up to them.

“I can tell you from my perspective, as the brother of Princess Leia, I would love it if they would carry on with Carrie,” Fisher said with a smile. “I mean how do you separate Princess Leia at this point from all of that? I mean it is a foundation of the story. She is a pivotal character that the world has come to love. Technically, obviously, we live in a time where that could be done easily where she could be brought in and out. I would love it.”

When asked if it was difficult to watch his sister in the movies, Todd acknowledged one moment in the The Last Jedi was emotionally heavy.

“I loved The Last Jedi and I the only thing that was difficult was the scene with Carrie in a coma — that was startling,” Fisher shared. “I’m sitting in the theater and Carrie had just been in a coma in real life and doesn’t make it. And, you know, as the brother you’re like, ‘What am I watching here?’“

“She was chosen to lead your resistance.”

While the Star Wars franchise might no longer feature Princess Leia, she’s alive and well as a symbol for the Trump-era “resistance” movement. The Women’s March has been just one of several political events that Carrie Fisher’s Leia was a prominent symbol on pickets.

“Carrie was outspoken,” Todd pointed out. “She was she was a powerful woman who didn’t take anything off of anybody and I shudder to think if you want to go up against Carrie. She also lived her life in an inspirational way. This is a woman that suffered from bipolar disorder, drug addiction. And yet through all of that was able to accomplish so many things.”

Princess Leia was featured on many signs at the Women’s March in 2017:

I know where she stood. You know where she stood. Such an honor to see her standing with you today. Bigly. #Resistance #WorldWideWomensMarch pic.twitter.com/cwsgoYVSU7

— Mark Hamill (@HamillHimself) January 21, 2017

“It’s all how you look at it,” he continued. “And she looked at life from the bright side in that regard and survived really well. And when the movement was taking place in Washington and they had Carrie’s picture you know, the Princess Leia picture, I mean I knew she’d be happy with that. It wasn’t about the politics. It was just about the idea that she was chosen to lead your resistance…whatever that meant to you.”

My Girls is currently available in stores and online.

Watch: The writers of  Last Action Hero reveal how Carrie Fisher contributed to their movie:

Read more from Yahoo Entertainment:

  • ‘Return of the Jedi’ at 35: The secret history of Leia’s golden bikini
  • How ‘Star Wars: Episode IX’ can give Princess Leia the ending she deserves
  • ‘The Last Jedi’: All the Easter eggs, callbacks, and cameos in the new ‘Star Wars’ (spoilers!)

Toward the end of her life, Carrie embraced her affected British accent in her scene with the “foul” Grand Moff Tarkin (Peter Cushing), but in 1977 she was horrified that it was being used in the final cut of the film.

“She was she freaked out when that was used because out of nowhere, the whole movie she has no British accent, and all of the sudden she has a British accent,” Fisher told us. “But you know what? I think she was the only one that noticed. I don’t think anybody cared! She was trained at the London Dramatic Academy. And of course they made you do Elizabethan English and such so you did have a tendency, if you’re being dramatic, to break loose with the British accent.”

“As the brother of Princess Leia, I would love it if they would carry on with Carrie.”

When Carrie Fisher died unexpectedly in 2016, the producers of Star Wars had to rework the script to the upcoming Episode IX, due out in 2019 because the actress was to have a major role. Because Leia’s story will not conclude as originally envisioned, and because fans wanted the iconic hero to get a deserving send-off, some launched a petition to have the role recast with Meryl Streep. Others suggested they employ similar technology used in Rogue One and have character return via CGI. Todd himself told the New York Daily News in 2017 that his late sister would appear in the upcoming Episode IX via unused footage. However, Lucasfilm President Kathleen Kennedy refuted that notion in a conversation with Yahoo at Star Wars Celebration a few weeks later, saying, “I have no idea why he said that.” Lucasfilm soon after released a statement saying the studio had “no plans to digitally recreate Carrie Fisher’s performance as Princess or General Leia Organa” in future movies.

Todd knows that the decision is out of his hands, but still hopes The Last Jedi won’t be the last movie Carrie appears in.

“Obviously Lucasfilm and Disney, they own Carrie’s likeness,” he acknowledged. “George owned it [before selling Lucasfilm]. In fact, Carrie famously used to joke that every time she looks in the mirror, she has to send George a couple of bucks. Now Disney’s got it. And what they do with it is up to them.

“I can tell you from my perspective, as the brother of Princess Leia, I would love it if they would carry on with Carrie,” Fisher said with a smile. “I mean how do you separate Princess Leia at this point from all of that? I mean it is a foundation of the story. She is a pivotal character that the world has come to love. Technically, obviously, we live in a time where that could be done easily where she could be brought in and out. I would love it.”

When asked if it was difficult to watch his sister in the movies, Todd acknowledged one moment in the The Last Jedi was emotionally heavy.

“I loved The Last Jedi and I the only thing that was difficult was the scene with Carrie in a coma — that was startling,” Fisher shared. “I’m sitting in the theater and Carrie had just been in a coma in real life and doesn’t make it. And, you know, as the brother you’re like, ‘What am I watching here?’“

“She was chosen to lead your resistance.”

While the Star Wars franchise might no longer feature Princess Leia, she’s alive and well as a symbol for the Trump-era “resistance” movement. The Women’s March has been just one of several political events that Carrie Fisher’s Leia was a prominent symbol on pickets.

“Carrie was outspoken,” Todd pointed out. “She was she was a powerful woman who didn’t take anything off of anybody and I shudder to think if you want to go up against Carrie. She also lived her life in an inspirational way. This is a woman that suffered from bipolar disorder, drug addiction. And yet through all of that was able to accomplish so many things.”

Princess Leia was featured on many signs at the Women’s March in 2017:

I know where she stood. You know where she stood. Such an honor to see her standing with you today. Bigly. #Resistance #WorldWideWomensMarch pic.twitter.com/cwsgoYVSU7

— Mark Hamill (@HamillHimself) January 21, 2017

“It’s all how you look at it,” he continued. “And she looked at life from the bright side in that regard and survived really well. And when the movement was taking place in Washington and they had Carrie’s picture you know, the Princess Leia picture, I mean I knew she’d be happy with that. It wasn’t about the politics. It was just about the idea that she was chosen to lead your resistance…whatever that meant to you.”

My Girls is currently available in stores and online.

Watch: The writers of  Last Action Hero reveal how Carrie Fisher contributed to their movie:

Read more from Yahoo Entertainment:

  • ‘Return of the Jedi’ at 35: The secret history of Leia’s golden bikini
  • How ‘Star Wars: Episode IX’ can give Princess Leia the ending she deserves
  • ‘The Last Jedi’: All the Easter eggs, callbacks, and cameos in the new ‘Star Wars’ (spoilers!)

trail.content_raw:
Before becoming an intergalactic icon, Carrie Fisher was a promising up-and-comer famous for being the daughter of Debbie Reynolds and Eddie Fisher. And even though she landed a lead role in a major studio film, Carrie wondered whether appearing in the strange new sci-fi adventure titled Star Wars would do irreparable damage to her acting career.

Her younger brother, Todd Fisher, was by her side during the making of George Lucas‘s film and at the world premiere. He joined Yahoo Entertainment in Los Angeles to share what it was like to accompany Carrie on the cusp of superstardom.

“She was squeezing my hand, panicked.”

“I was with [Carrie] in England when the movie was being made,” says Fisher, whose new memoir, My Girls, offers a peek at what it was like to grow up in Hollywood with Carrie and mother Debbie Reynolds. “It was cool. There was these big sets and it had a certain amount of impressiveness to the sets. But you know you couldn’t obviously see any of the effects so you don’t know what’s coming. And you know, people [thought Lucas was] all nuts. He’s got this giant 7-foot carpet running around called a Wookiee. …

“So we’re sitting in the parking lot waiting to go into the screening,” Fisher continued. “Now, this is the first time anybody’s seen anything. This is days before it comes out to the theaters. She’s smoking, chain-smoking, drinking —  Coca-Cola in one hand, cigarette in the other hand. She just doesn’t want to go and I’m like, ‘You know we’ve got to go in.’  I’m sitting there watching the lights go down, you know, literally doors are closing. ‘We’ve got to go now.’ So I finally get her to put her cigarette out. By this point there’s nowhere to sit except the front row. So we sit in the front row and it starts and we watch those titles go by and then the battlecruiser flies over and I looked over, and I had her hand, she was squeezing my hand, panicked. I said, ‘This is no B-movie.‘”

Toward the end of her life, Carrie embraced her affected British accent in her scene with the “foul” Grand Moff Tarkin (Peter Cushing), but in 1977 she was horrified that it was being used in the final cut of the film.

“She was she freaked out when that was used because out of nowhere, the whole movie she has no British accent, and all of the sudden she has a British accent,” Fisher told us. “But you know what? I think she was the only one that noticed. I don’t think anybody cared! She was trained at the London Dramatic Academy. And of course they made you do Elizabethan English and such so you did have a tendency, if you’re being dramatic, to break loose with the British accent.”

“I loved The Last Jedi and I the only thing that was difficult was the scene with Carrie in a coma — that was startling,” Fisher shared. “I’m sitting in the theater and Carrie had just been in a coma in real life and doesn’t make it. She also lived her life in an inspirational way. This is a woman that suffered from bipolar disorder, drug addiction. And yet through all of that was able to accomplish so many things.”

I know where she stood. You know where she stood. Such an honor to see her standing with you today. Bigly. #Resistance #WorldWideWomensMarch pic.twitter.com/cwsgoYVSU7

— Mark Hamill (@HamillHimself) January 21, 2017

And when the movement was taking place in Washington and they had Carrie’s picture you know, the Princess Leia picture, I mean I knew she’d be happy with that. It wasn’t about the politics. title: Why are people?
body:
There’s someone on Twitter (i don’t know their gender) who thinks that in the latest SW, *Holdo’s purple hair and fancy dress* makes it ridiculous that she would hold command and be respected as such.

I’m just….

… Sorry, wrong universe. But she belongs anyway.

Also, it’s EVEN MORE absurd in the Star Wars universe - where dudes desperately try to outdo each other in Dramatic Clothing™, only to be once again left in the dust by the mfucker queens…

Seriously, you call yourselves ~real fans~, pretending to be objectively and reasonably criticizing things… and this is what you go after? Come on. You’re reaching so hard, you’re going to pull a muscle.

summary: It’s been a long time coming, but I’ve returned to Youtube, on this: the date of the End of The Galaxy. To anyone who used to...
caption: It’s been a long time coming, but I’ve returned to Youtube, on this: the date of the End of The Galaxy. To anyone who used to watch my stuff, you’ll love this one. It’s focused on a single topic and yet it covers so much ground.
